title-group.article-title: Myth and Reality of the Khap Panchayats: A Historical Analysis of the Panchayat and Khap Panchayat*

contrib.aff: Associate Professor, Motilal Nehru College, University of Delhi, Delhi, India

abstract.p: During the past few years, marriages within ‘gotra’ (clan) of the Jat community have come into the limelight. Frequently, those couples who have eloped have been brutally murdered by the diktats of the elders—these are known as ‘honour killings’. Many such incidents have occurred in Haryana, Western Uttar Pradesh and the rural belt of Delhi. These areas have reaped the fruits of modernization and access to various facilities such as educational institutions, health centres, modernized roads and multinational business establishments that have encouraged foreign investment. There exists a vast gulf between this modernization and the almost feudal mind sets of people like the ‘Khap Panchayats’ who force couples who have entered intra-gotra marriages to return to the community fold, even to the extent of forcing the couples to live like siblings. A large number of such wedded couples have even lost their lives. Thus, as per their gotra affinity, the Khap Panchayats consider them as brother and sister. The Khap Panchayats try to legitimize their actions by quoting historical antecedents of uncertain origin to support their practices. They are of the opinion that the Khap Panchayat is an age old institution, having its foundation in the early medieval period.

body.p: Historical appropriation of legitimacy by socially and economically upward mobile castes is not a new phenomenon and it has gained unfortunate importance in contemporary times.1 The reasons for such fabricated claims are numerous but representative democracy appears to have played an important role in fostering such tendencies. In the age of globalization and growing consumerism the retention of such identity has led groups to enforce self-promulgated caste rules and regulations. It is therefore, not surprising to note the dictates issued by Khap panchayats in and around Delhi region to regulate the ‘gotra’ marriages in their community. Such attempts at regulation unfortunately have frequently ended in gruesome ‘honour killings’. These have assumed alarming proportions in recent times and pose a serious threat to the democratic and constitutional functioning of civil society. In this article an attempt is made to investigate the historical basis of the Khap panchayats on the basis of documents, particularly Indo-Persian and Rajasthani historical sources.

According to a recent survey carried out by Shakti Vahini with the help of the National Women’s Commission, for the year 2008–2009, 354 cases of violence related to ‘honour killings’ have been analyzed (on data taken from First Information Reports [FIRs]). It was found that 72 per cent of cases are related to inter-caste marriages, 3 per cent are related to same gotra marriages, 15 per cent of cases were related to the non-consent of parents. Thus only 2.4 cases fall under the category of gotra marriage.2 What is surprising to note is the fact that most of these so called ‘crimes’ are instigated on the directives of panchayats. It is all together a different matter that most of these panchayats have practically no legal or constitutional rights. Most of the time, these panchayats claim legitimacy attributed to some long historical tradition or certain social conventions.

Information about the history of the Sarvakhap Panchayat is introduced to us by the unpublished handwritten Pothi of Pandit KanhaRam, resident of village Shauram, in the district of Muzaffarnagar. He has discussed some historical incidents pertaining to Khap Panchayats in his Pothi. The Pothi consists of 16 hand written pages, describing the locations and dates of Khap Panchayat meetings.3 According to the Pothi, the first meeting of the Sarvakhap Panchayat was held in the forest of Baraut in VS 1252 (1195 AD). It took the decision to raise an army against the attacks of Mohammad Ghori.4 This seems to be fictitious as there is no corroborating evidence to support this claim. The closest reference of Jats during this time suggests that in 1192, after the defeat of Prithviraj Chauhan, the farmers, in the area around Hansi (Haryana) revolted under the leadership of Jatwan. Qutubuddin Aibak suppressed the revolt.5 The most plausible reason for this revolt seems to be the opposition to the new land revenue policy implemented by the Turks. Further, the Pothi suggests that another meeting of the Khap Panchayat was held in VS 1455 (1398 AD) in the forests of Chaugama, in the district of Muzaffarnagar. The purpose of this meeting as stated in the Pothi was to resist the onslaughts of the attacks of Taimur Lane.6 However the autobiography of Taimur, Malfuzat-e-Tamuri, tells us that Jats troubled him a lot in the areas around Tohana (near Hissar), but does not mention any opposition from the Jats in the area closer to the forests of Chaugama, in the district of Muzaffarnagar. Further he writes that when his army was sent, the Jats used to hide in the nearby cane fields7 and thus avoided direct confrontation. Moreover, it is important to note that when Taimur attacked the areas adjoining Meerut and Haridwar, nowhere do we find any evidence that he had faced any resistance from the Jats.

Subsequently, the Sarvakhap Panchayat also claims that they had sent an army of 5000 soldiers in favour of Rana Sanga against Babur in the battle of Sikari (Khanwa) in 1527 AD.8 However, in the absence of corroborative evidence it is again difficult to verify this claim. Moreover, Babur who has mentioned almost all the rulers and communities who fought in favour of Rana Sanga does not mention the Jats as his adversaries. Similarly another Sarvakhap Panchayat was supposedly held in VS 1718 (1661 AD) in Chaprauli, a place located in the vicinity of Meerut and Muzaffarnagar. Its purpose was to oppose the Jazia tax imposed by Mughal Emperor Aurangzeb and he was requested to roll it back.9 But the date of this Sarvakhap Panchayat does not tally with the date of the Jazia tax that Aurangzeb imposed in 1679 ADon Hindus in the 22nd year of his reign.10 The Jat revolt of 1668 under the leadership of Gokula Jat also had nothing to do with the Jazia tax. It was a peasants’ revolt which took place in the region of Mathura because of the increasing land revenue burden during the reign of Aurangzeb.11

The Sarvakhap Panchayat claims that in the third battle of Panipat which was fought between Ahmad Shah Abdali and the Marathas, they had sent an army of 22,000 soldiers under the leadership of Chaudhary Shirlal Jat of Shaurabh village, district Muzaffarnagar, in the support of the Marathas.12 This information also is not supported by historical sources. It is a well known fact that the Jat Raja of Bharatpur, Surajmal, did not extended any help to the Marathas in this battle. Therefore to claim that the Sarvakhap Panchayat had sent such a huge army for the support of the Marathas13 appears more fiction than fact.

It is not surprising to note that the Jats rely on Pandit KanhaRam’s handwritten pothi to legitimize the historical role of the Khap Panchayat. Interestingly, it is written in modern Hindi. At present, this pothi is in possession of Chaudhuri Kabul Singh of Shauram village in the district of Muzaffarnagar. This Pothi claims that there had been a total of 24 meetings of Sarvakhap Panchayat from 1252 to VS 1817 (1195–1760 AD). To further their claims of legitimacy, out of these, 8 meetings were held during the reign of Mughal Emperors and the rest prior to the reign of Akbar.14 Some of the dates mentioned herein do not tally with actual historical dates. Apart from these dates, the incidents described in this Pothi, again, do not correspond to contemporary historical sources on the basis of which these events can be co-related with facts.

As a matter of fact, it is really difficult to accept the claims of the Sarvakhap Panchayats since the way they represent the nature of warfare they undertook against the invaders (Mohammad Ghori, Taimur Lane, Babar and Ahmad Shah Abdali) is utterly unreliable. First, the efforts to organize armies seem unrealistic without state support; Second, how could such a national awakening arise in the Sarvakhap Panchayats, whereas the country as a whole only experienced such an awakening in the nineteenth century? The best example of this could be seen in the revolt of 1857 where the majority of Indian rulers supported the British to suppress masses of rebels.

The authenticity of the pothis needs to be examined on the basis of linguistic characters as well to rule out any ambiguity. Since the pothis claim long-standing historical legitimacy, it is but natural to expect that the language will correspond to contemporary traditions. Even a cursory look at the language of these pothis makes it amply clear that these were written in Khari Boli Hindi and do not resemble the language used in the early nineteenth century. It appears that the Chaudhary of Shauram village (Mujaffarnagar District) got such a history fabricated by Pandit Kanharam. The pothis claim repeatedly that the Khap Panchayats fought against the atrocities of the medieval rulers. However, it is surprising to note that historically validated incidents of Jat revolts do not figure in these pothis. When Mohammad Tughlaq increased the land revenue on these areas of Western UP (Ganga–Jamuna Doab) by 20 per cent in comparison with other areas, the farmers could not pay such a heavy revenue during the famine. Mohammad Tughlaq sent an army to quell the protest and the majority of farmers fled to the forest.15 Given the practice of holding Khap Panchayats, one would expect a meeting of the Sarvakhap Panchayat at this juncture.

Similarly, during the reign of Aurangzeb, in the year 1668, there was a fierce battle under the leadership of Gokula Jat near Mathura, and the Emperor Aurangzeb had to send an army to suppress the Jats. Gokula was publically beheaded.16 After this, Aurangzeb adopted a policy of suppressing the Jats and the latter were not allowed to assemble, except for a single meeting against the Jazia. Keeping in view this description, the pothi of Pandit Kanharam cannot be treated as an authentic source.

M.C. Pradhan, a sociologist, in his work titled The Political System of the Jats of Northern India, has made extensive use of Pundit Kanharam’s Pothi for his research.17 As a matter of fact, this work was published at a time when in Western Uttar Pradesh, the Jats were trying to establish their political identity under the leadership of Chaudhary Charan Singh. This book however, was not taken seriously by historians.

The legitimacy of these Khap Panchayats do not rest on validated historical evidence. The historicity of the so called records of these panchayats has been used to legitimize their claims. This explains why it poses a major challenge to historians. In this article I have tried to discuss the nature of the village panchayat during the Mughal period, along with investigations into Khap Panchayats and gotras (clan) of Jats.

The origin of the word ‘Khap’ is derived from ‘faank’, meaning an off-shoot or fraction. Historically the word ‘Khap’ was used for the first time in Rajasthan in the context of Rajput ruling class during the medieval period. In Muhnaut Naiansi ri vigat or the Khyats of Marwar state, we find that the word ‘Khap’ has extensively been used in the context of different sects of the Rajput ruling class. The first Census report based on religion and caste was prepared in Jodhpur in the year 1890–1891, thereby dividing the people of India on the basis of religion and caste. Even the castes were divided on the basis of gotras.18 The word ‘Khap’ has come into existence in the said Census report. When it was translated into Hindi, the word class instead of being coined as ‘gotra’ was termed as ‘Khap’. For example, Murdumshumari Raj Marwar was a census that divided the people of all castes in the year 1891 into ‘gotras’—meaning thereby khaps. Different khaps of the Jat caste have been described.19 Khap Panchayat means the panchayat of the villagers who belonged to the same gotra. Thus different gotras had their own Khap Panchayats. Khap Panchayats believe themselves to be autonomous from the State and claim to represent all members of that particular community.

sec.title: Historical Evidence of Panchayat
sec.p: To understand the working style, significance and the nature of Khap Panchayats, it is very important for us to understand the organization of the Mughal village panchayat systems. The Khap Panchayat can be seen as a panchayat at the micro-level. The study of village communities and panchayat organizations in India was carried out mainly by scholars such as Sir Henry Maine, Elphinstone, Baden Powell, Charles Metcalfe and James Mill, who also occupied various posts in the British East India Company. The main objective of these administrators was to trace land ownership and revenue payment patterns. In order to adequately address these objectives they realized that the heads of the villages were the most feasible category for the purpose. The British administrators ignored the fact that often, ownership of the land was vested in the farmers and preferred to assign collection of revenue to the local kings. Following the battle of Buxar in 1764, the East India Company became the sole master of the entire land of Bengal, Bihar and Orissa. Subsequently, the study of the village community was also carried out by British administrative officers and therefore they can be held responsible for the propagation of the concept of the village community and the panchayat.

The general understanding of village communities and panchayat organizations was largely based on the descriptions of the European travellers (especially Bernier) rather than on the documents of the Mughal period. This may explain why they compared the Indian village community to the Russian Mir and the German Mark.20 It is interesting to note that no one refuted these beliefs, even during the period of national struggle in India. Gradually new research offered new perspectives and earlier theories were slowly demolished. What was the nature of the village panchayat in the Mughal period? What were its functions and role? To understand all this, we need to go back to the village panchayat system during the Mughal era. Basically, one can say that the village panchayats were neither autonomous, nor free, but their functioning was greatly influenced by external forces. Even among modern historians, there is no unanimity regarding the village panchayat organizations during the Mughal period. Irfan Habib is of the opinion that North India never had a village panchayat system during the Mughal period.21 B.R. Grover has also refuted the existence of the panchayat system. According to him, if there had been the village panchayat administration system, then there would have been no need for the Mughals to appoint officials like Chaudhary and Quanungo at the village level. Dilbagh Singh in his study on Eastern Rajasthan lays emphasis on the idea of the village panchayat and suggests that the organization did exist in the later Mughal period. He is of the opinion that the larger and more developed villages had the panchayat system, whose members however, were mainly from the upper class of the village such as Chaudhary, Quanungo, Patel and Zamindar, along with people from upper castes such as Brahmin and Mahajans.22 But whether an ordinary farmer or a person from the weaker section of society could be a member remains doubtful. However, there are no documents available for historians in Rajasthani and Indo-Persian sources that throw light on this subject or that can describe the village panchayat organization and its nature in the Mughal period.

But at times, we do find references to the panchayat in some Rajasthani documents. For example, if there was a dispute concerning the border (Kankad) of two villages, then the Quanungo and Chaudhary (Pargana Officials) used to invite Patels of 12 villages for resolving the dispute.23 The Patel by virtue of his being the head of village also used to be the head of panchayat or council, though it is not clear about who else constituted the village panchayats. Nevertheless, it is important to realize that the Parganas that constitute the area of concern for our purposes used to be part of the Delhi and Agra Subas. Administratively, the majority of these Parganas, being part of Delhi Suba were usually designated as ‘khalisa’. The region of Western UP, Delhi’s rural belt and the majority of Haryana being in close proximity to the imperial court meant that these were either classified as khalisa or were part of jagirs of imperial Mansabdars.24

Thus, the administrative organization at the pargana and the village level of these areas was in full administrative control of the officials of the Mughal State. At the local level, the Patwari used to play a pivotal role; his sole responsibility was to maintain a record of all statistics pertaining to land revenue and the agricultural production of each peasant of each village. Even the Malba tax from the farmers was collected with the help of the Patwari.25 The Patel, along with being the head of the village, also functioned as a semi-government official whose job was to collect land revenue from the farmers and deposit it in the office of the Amil.26 A ‘Sahna’ was also appointed in each village as the farmers had to pay the land revenue in the ‘batai–jinsi’ system—a crop sharing system for revenue realization. It was also the Sahna’s job to keep watch on standing crops.27

The Sahna had to be vigilant and ensure that no farmer would take home the harvested crop without paying land revenue to the State. This used to be the major reason of skirmishes between the farmers and the Sahnas. There is evidence that points to the Mughal State instructing the farmers not to quarrel or to misbehave with the Sahna.28 Even so, we hear about skirmishes between the two. The Patwari and Patel exercised their functions at the local level which the Qanungo and Chaudhary worked at the pargana level.

The responsibility to look after theft, dacoity and to maintain law and order seems to have been that of the Faujdar.29 The Faujdar’s responsibility was also to penalize farmers who failed to pay land revenue charges. The Amil was the highest administrative official whose responsibility was to oversee the collection process of the land revenue with the help of subordinate officials. Thus the land revenue administration at the village level was managed by the Pargana and local administrative officials. That is why the Patels and the Patwaris were directed to make a list of farmers with disputes and to submit these to the Amil.

Various sources provide evidence of how the Amil resolved disputes between farmers. For example, in the year 1680, Kesho Jat of the Ratoli village (the village near Hodal, Pargana Shahar) had complained in the Darbar of the Amil that while Aaso Jat of Moja Jatoti had engaged his daughter to his son, he had proceeded to marry her off instead to the son of Ratna Jat of Moja Jonai. The enquiry by the Amil revealed that the complaint was true and the latter imposed a fine of ₹5 on Asa Jat.30 Similarly, when there was a fight between Khema and Godu Jat in Moja Taroli, the Faujdar imposed a fine of ₹18, and 8 annas on both farmers.31 In Mauja Dhanauli, Raruka and Kisna Jat raped the wife of Tikku Jat and both men were fined ₹44 and ₹33 respectively by the Amil.32 Similarly, the son of the Khema Jat of Gudha village raped Daala Jat’s daughter; consequently Khema Jat was fined ₹41 by the Amil. It seems that the investigative authority was also vested with the Amil. Thus it appears that there was apparently very limited function or role for the panchayats even in resolving intra-caste disputes.

In another situation, the land of four villages of the Meos was encroached upon by the Jats of Khoh village of pargana Kama. The Quanungo and the Chaudhary were directed by higher authorities to resolve the dispute with the help of the Patels of the respective villages.33 In another case, Chaukha Jat Patel of village Khairal of Pargana Shahar reaped the harvest of a sugarcane field of 5½ bighas without taking the permission of the Sahna. Thereafter, following on from the complaint made by the Sahna, the Amil of the pargana imposed a fine of ₹7 on the Patel. When the Patel abused the Sahna, the latter booked a complaint in the court of the Amil and the Patel, too, was summoned. The Patel however failed to appear. Sources reveal that the penalty on the Patel was enhanced to the tune of ₹231 because of his callous attitude and continued disregard of the law of the land.34 It is evident that most disputes and matters of unlawful behaviour were adjudicated and resolved by lower state-level officials.

Moreover, there is no reference of any aggrieved party ever approaching the panchayat for redressal of their complaints. For example, Harji Patel in Mauja Khedli did not get his cane field measured for revenue assessment. When this lapse was discovered by the Amil, a fine of ₹27 was imposed. Without the knowledge of the Sahna, Khema Jat of Mauja Morda destroyed the maize and bottle gourd was sown in 4 bighas. Following up on the Sahna’s complaint, a fine of ₹7½ was imposed by the Amil.35 In another case, in the year 1665, Puran Patel of Mauja Bhau, Jagga Patel of Bhirhi Kalan and Lala Patel of village Kaadma (Pargana Chalkalyan) had reported a number of quarrels between the farmers and the Amil. The Amil received a fine of ₹1064 in lieu of penalties.36

To further substantiate my argument I have chosen a few cases of the crimes involving the Jats of the region. For this purpose, we examined another set of Rajasthani documents named ‘Chithiyaat’ wherein we find the information concerning the disputes of the farmers and the Patels regarding land holdings. The major part of the information in these documents relates to the villages of the Pargana of Eastern Rajasthan which were given to the Rajput Kachchwah Raja in his Tankhawah Jagir. But some of the Chithis also shed significant light on the villages of Narnaul, Kama, Pahari, Hodal and Bharatpur areas, inhabited mainly by Jat peasants. Interestingly, we do not get any reference to Khap Panchayat, though village-level disputes find frequent mention. Similarly, the ‘Khatutahalkaran’, a secret report concerning the activities of the farmers does not mention the term Khap Panchayat. In this context, it is imperative to discuss the Vakil reports as well. These reports were prepared by the Vakils of the Amber Raja posted at the Mughal Darbar. These reports bring to light the revolts and other activities of the Jats but give us no information about the Khap Panchayats. Similarly, the Ain-i-Akbari informs us that the majority of the Jat villages of Haryana, Western Uttar Pradesh and countryside of Delhi formed part of the Delhi Suba in the Mughal administrative system.37 Most of the Parganas were given to the Imperial Mansabdars as Tankhwah Jagir or were designated ‘Khalisa’ (Imperial land). Therefore it will not be incorrect to assume that the Mughal State had devised a system of local governance whereby a stringent control over the region could be maintained. Had the Khap Panchayat of Jats been in existence, would there not have been some reference to them? Furthermore, the activities of the Khap Panchayats would also have found some mention in any one of the Indo-Persian or Rajasthani sources which are fairly detailed. Moreover, the meetings of the Khap Panchayats as claimed by Pothis, were mega-events, and should have attracted the attention of the administrative set-up, which was closely involved even in petty interpersonal disputes in their realm. It is difficult to believe that such large assemblies do not find any mention in all the recorded information and contemporary documents pertaining to the medieval phase.
I would like to submit that the village panchayat system existed during the Mughal period; however it is still difficult for scholars to define its character, role and functions.

The Khuts and Mukadams functioned as representatives of the village community during the Sultanate period; similarly, the Patel who was a member of the peasant community served as the head of the village community during the Mughal period. The social and economic position of the Patel used to be much higher and influential than other farmers. He was the head of the village community and his duty was also to assist in the collection of land revenue from his fellow farmers. He was in constant touch with the Amil and the Faujdar.38 A few elderly peasants may have helped the Patel, though we do not have any evidence that points to the presence of village councils. It seems clear that while most disputes were resolved by the Amil, some minor conflicts and village welfare work was deputed to the village council, under the leadership of the Patel. However, records show that farmers did raise their grievances, even against the Patels, to the Mughal court.

Apparently, Village Panchayats were never recognized by the Mughal state. Their major role was to assist the state officials (Amil, Faujdar, Amin, Chaudhary and Quanungo) with the help of the Patel and the village council, whenever these officials happened to visit the village for the purpose of measuring village land or for other reasons. The Patel with the help of other members of the village council used to provide them food and shelter and even transport facilities in the form of bullock carts.39 With the help of the Patwari, the village council used the Malba tax to undertake various infrastructure projects such as construction of dams and water bodies, particularly in the rainy season. The Village Councils also played a major role in resolving farmers’ disputes over land, water, cattle and other such local level problems.40

After the fall of the Mughal Empire, as the position of administrative officials waned, village councils assumed greater importance in resolving disputes between farmers. Moreover, the position of the Zamindars and the Patels got strengthened in the village community and the colonial authorities used this opportunity to absorb them in their own administrative structure. It is this changed situation that has been described by British administrative officers like Baden Powell, Sir Henry Maine, Elphinstone, Metcalfe and James Mill among others.

In the beginning of the nineteenth century, the Jat leaders claimed their hereditary position and exercised control over the peasantry. Those villagers who disobeyed orders were given severe punishments. Generally Jat chieftains were looked on with favour as being impartial. The Maharaja of Jodhpur, Bakhatwar Singh was often known to consult the Jat head of Jhanwar village in complex cases.41

sec.title: Gotras
sec.p: Since Khap Panchayats generally comprise and correspond to different gotras of Jats, a brief survey is given in this section to place them in a historical context. The Jats are divided into a number of gotras (clans), unmatched by any other community. According to prescriptive literature concerning the Hindu caste system, the gotras play a pivotal role. The popular perception about gotras is that they are based on the common ancestor’s name. That is why people belonging to the same gotra are tied together with a feeling of brotherhood. This is also the reason that Khap Panchayats have opposed intra-gotra marriages and now wish to bring about an amendment in the Hindu Marriage Act. The gotra seems to consist of an evolved institution coming down from ancient times in Hindu society. R.S. Sharma defines the term ‘gotra’ to mean ‘Gaushala’ that means cowherds42 and suggests that it evolved during the Rigvedic period. Since Rigvedic society was basically a cattle rearing community, it indicates that the formation of gotras must have been along economic lines. People of a particular group used to maintain a Gaushala, and their survival depended on the sale of milk. Historians suggest that because of their co-operation with each other and the feeling of brotherhood, the people of a single Gaushala were termed as belonging to the one gotra.43 This is viewed as the basis of the origin of the gotra system in Rigvedic society. With the shift to agriculture from cattle rearing, the gotras started being identified with different farming settlements instead of Gaushalas. As tribal society gradually turned into a farming community, new gotras sprang up. The process was rapid and by the beginning of the medieval period the number of gotras had increased to 500.44 Hence, a number of pastoral tribal communities transformed themselves into agriculturalists and subsequently, caste became the basis around which gotra identities crystallized. Many of these communities subsequently asserted themselves as organized armed groups to make their presence felt and to evolve their specific identities.

The earliest information that we have about the Jats is available in the Chachnama. It is mentioned that in 809 AD, the Jats reared cattle in the area of Sindh.45 During the phase of the Delhi Sultanate, the Jats emerged as an important farming community in the area of Punjab. Abul Fazl in his Ain-i-Akbari describes the Jats as among the best farmers in the north western region. Later on, Jats acquired a large number of Zamindaris in Delhi and Agra Subas.46 In the late eighteenth century, French writer Wendel writes that ‘Jat means having a plough’.47 The French writer Modave writes:
[A]lthough the Jats are gentle people and if they are not forced to take arms, they take delight in farming on their free will. For me, the hard work of the Jats is appreciable because of the fact, that they have not left the earth unploughed and their fields are far better maintained.48

The above description indicates the fact that to be recognized as an important farming community and to shed their traditional characterization as a pastoral community, the Jats had to struggle for a very long time.

Recent research indicates that the Jats got transformed into an agrarian community only after the twelfth and thirteenth centuries.49 So, it is clear that their gotra identity could have got solidified only after that period. The word ‘Jat’ is usually found in Indo-Persian sources after the establishment of the Delhi Sultanate (1206 AD), particularly in north India. The writer of the Tarikh-i-Firozshahi, Shams Siraz Afif, mentions that there were a number of ‘kharaks’ between Sirsa and Hansi.50 Kharak is a Persian word meaning ‘cow herds’, and we deduce that these places also had a number of areas dedicated to cow rearing. Cow rearing was an important occupation in medieval India, not only for its dairy produce but also because the ox was a very important means of transport for carrying goods. Transportation of grains and foodstuff was carried out by the Banjara community and they were in possession of thousands of oxen.51 Afif writes that when Firozshah Tughlaq thought of establishing a new city named Hisar Firoza, there were already two big villages there. One was big Laras and the other small Laras. The big one had 50 and the small one had 40 ‘kharaks’. There was no village in the whole area without a kharak.52 The geographical location of the area attracted the attention of the Sultan, who established a new city named Hissar. But there was a scarcity of water there. In summers, when traders from Iraq and Khurasan used to visit these areas, they had to buy a glass of water for 4 Jitals—a kind of currency, which was one twenty-fifth of a dam.53 Afif also informs us that the Jats had still not completely transformed themselves into a farming community. Apparently, one section of the Jat community was still associated with the breeding of cattle (kharak) and then selling the oxen to the Banjaras. Their social identity was known by the gotras they were associated with, such as, Bachda (small ox), Baidka (young ox), Bail and Dhanda (old ox). Thus the kharaks were known by the type of cattle they dealt with and gradually the families associated with the kharaks, too, took their identity from the types of cattle that they were rearing.

Afif further mentions that Firozshah Tughlaq decided to dig canals and connect them to the rivers because of the prevalent water scarcity. Two canals were dug linking them to Hissar Firoza: one named Rajibaha was from the Yamuna and the other, named Ulagkhani came from the Satluj. Both these canals, after passing from Karnal, used to connect Hissar Firoza via Hansi.54 Afif writes that there were a number of towns and villages located along the course of these canals, like Jind, Dhatrath, Hansi, Safidon and so on, which benefited significantly from the canal water. Before these canals were dug it was possible to grow only the Kharif crop in the Hissar area. Thereafter the cultivation of the rabi crop also came up since the wheat crop was not possible without water.55 Before this we read about Hansi ‘Shiq’ (an administrative unit), implying that this area of Hissar was a part of the Hansi Shiq from the administrative point of view. But subsequently, the Sultan ordered that the Shiq be transferred to Hissar. So Hansi, Agroha, Fatehabad and from Sirsa to Salora and Khijarbad—all these areas were included in the Hissar Shiq, and Malik Delan was appointed as the Shiqdar of this area.56

Firozshah established another city in between Hissar Firoza and Sirsa, which was named Fatehabad. On one occasion when the Sultan was travelling to Delhi from Sirsa on the way, a child was born to his wife. The child was named Fateh Khan and the township was named after him. Ziauddin Barani writes that villages became settled and multiplied because of the irrigation facilities in this area. As the subjects took to agriculture, they produced many crops. Earlier, due to the scarcity of water, there used to be a number of Tilodi or (group of bullock carts) found in this area and people lived in bullock carts instead of villages.57

Wherever the Tilodi found water, they settled permanently and built up habitations. With the establishment of the canals and due to better administration under the Sultans, these ‘Tilodis’ transformed into villages and the settlers gave up the practice of sleeping under the bullock carts. Scarcity of water did not allow any crop except the hardy ‘moth’ and ‘urd’. With the advent of canals, the farmers could also produce cane and wheat. The Central Asian invader, Tamurlaine, also described the sugarcane crop he happened to observe while he passed through Tohana. After the establishment of these villages, the administration improved drastically and the Kharaj (land revenue) collection became stable and systematic.58

The Kharaks were mainly found in the areas of Hansi, Hissar, Fatehabad, Sirsa and Jind where the Jat population was found in great density. We must be aware of the fact that Afif may have exaggerated these figures somewhat in order to please the Sultan. Evidence shows that by the fourteenth century, the transformation of Jats into an agrarian community was as yet incomplete. One section of the community still subsisted on cattle rearing. The scarcity of water did not allow them to settle down at any fixed place. Along with their cattle and families, they use to roam here and there for water and their usual abode was the Tilodi (bullock cart). The majority of kharaks were located where water was available in abundance. By and large agricultural productivity was also low because of the lack of water and only a few kharif crops were grown in these areas.

After the advent of canals, the region witnessed several important changes in the social and economic lives of the Jats. The availability of water increased the productivity in the area. Wheat and sugarcane could be grown in this region. These new possibilities of secure agricultural production offered fresh opportunities to the Jats to settle down as an agrarian community. The farmers who settled near the canals had to pay more revenue in comparison with others. Such farmers were classified as ‘Nehra’ by the land revenue officials. This classification of the farmers created a new social identity such as Nehra or Neharwal gotras. Afif writes that Firozshah had deputed a number of soldiers and officers to look after the canals so that the water could flow safely through the villages and towns.59

The Jats of Berwal also lived in Hissar. Originally, the Berwal Jats had carved out their settlements in region of Churu (Rajasthan). Later on after the fourteenth century, they moved towards the region of Hissar (Haryana). During the medieval period, the area of Berwal Jats was less fertile, with thorny bushes and berries. This fact is corroborated by Barani who states that that due to the scarcity of water, plum bushes and other thorny plants were found in plenty in the region of Hissar.60 The term ‘Ber’, also became associated with the social identity of Jat farmers of that area who were now known as ‘Berwal’. The Jats of the Malik gotra were not only found in Haryana but also in Western UP. The Malik gotra is not confined only to the Jats, but also refers to other Hindu castes, such as Punjabi, Harijans and Gujjar. We find this gotra in the Muslim population of Pakistan (around Lahore and Rawalpindi) too. During the Sultanate period, Malik used to be a title or rank in the army, just like Mansabdar in the Mughal army. So, the identification of this gotra emerged from military ranks.61 That is why people of this gotra are found among various castes. Similarly, the Dalal gotra, too was formed not on the basis of a common ancestor but on the basis of a certain profession. During the medieval period, the brokers who dealt with foodstuffs and grain were called ‘Dalal’. Some of the Jat gotras were formed on the criteria of localities, such as Punia, Sansanwal, Deshwal, Dahiya and Bagri. Other gotras like Tanwar, Panwar, Chauhan and Rana are common in Jats and Rajputs and other communities. Some other gotras common among Jats, Bishnois, Gujjars and Harijans are Godara, Kataria, and Gothwal.

The peacock is regarded as a totem of the Jats and they have a special respect for their emblem. Crook, while commenting on the Jats, has suggested that a few groups claim their origin with the peacock. For example, in Jind and Hissar districts of Haryana, the Jats have Moor and Banwala (Peacock) gotras. In fact the Jats of the Moor and Banwala gotras consider themselves brothers or fraternal groups.62

The Mardumshumari Rajmarwar, 1891, mentions that the Punia and Godara Jats are the oldest inhabitants of Western Rajasthan. Godara means those who possess cows.63 The Punia Jats, found in a majority in the Churu district of Rajasthan, are among the poorest Jat groups. They originate from a large village named Punia Jat, situated in the state of Bikaner.64 Some of the families whose livelihood was cattle rearing settled around Hissar. The place where cattle rearing took place was termed as Kharak Punia.65 In the Nagaur pargana of Rajasthan many of the Jat communities are known by their village names such as Indana, Mundel, Jalwania, Deedel, Dugolia and Varnagawan.66 Other regions like Bharatpur and Mathura also have Jat gotras derived from village names, such as Sinsiniwal, Sogaria and Sorot.67 By the end of the eighteenth century the Jats were thus able to form more than 250 gotras.68 The identity of the majority of Jats was based either on occupation, village, region or some kind of totem. The Jats used the gotras to forge a new social identity which was composite as well as specific.

Historical evidence pertaining to Jats appears increasingly in contemporary literature especially after the late seventeenth century with the beginning of agrarian revolts. A large number of Jat peasants and zamindars participated in revolts against the Mughal State to assert their own socio-economic position. The Mughal State deputed spies to provide information on the activities of the rebels. There is interesting information regarding a certain Jat named Churaman Jat who was a rebel fighting the Mughals. The information includes locations of fortresses, numerical strength of men and arsenals and strategies of how he would meet the Rajput bhumias while pretending to attend religious ceremonies.

Although one would expect the Khap Panchayat to play a key role during times of upheaval and mobilization, no such organization is mentioned in the reports. Had this organization been active in the Mughal period, it is needless to say that the land revenue officers and the spies would have mentioned and reported it to the Mughal authorities. Contrary to historical evidence, present day Khap Panchayats claim their existence at least from Mughal times. They also emphasize that they fought against the Mughal authorities. Even if the panchayats had conducted their meetings in the forests, this would have found mention in either the Mughal records or the Rajput and the Indo-Persian chronicles.

sec.title: The Jat Revolts
sec.p: Revolt against the Mughals in such an organized and sustained manner is a clear testimony of the enhanced socio-economic position of the Jats that encompassed some form of caste identity. Apparently the most important cause for the revolt during the late seventeenth and the early eighteenth century can be explained in the economic exploitation Jats suffered at the hands of the Mughal authorities. The Jat movement (1668–1735 AD) was a long struggle of farmers and zamindars that shook the Mughal State to its core. It is therefore, not surprising to note that the Jat revolt was chiefly centred around the areas of Agra, Mathura, Bharatpur, Delhi, Hodal, Palwal and Mewat. The Jat Revolts got their impetus from the collective strength of farmers and zamindars. Among the chief rebel leaders who provided direction and a sense of unity were Gokula, Rajaram, Bhojraj and Churaman. The credit for the collective struggles cannot however go to the Khap Panchayats since there is no evidence of their existence. Nor did the Khap Panchayats bear any record or criticize the atrocious actions of the Mughal emperor Aurangzeb who publically ordered the beheading of Gokula Jat.

Thousands of peasants belonging to different castes, such as Meena, Meo and Gujjar, were involved in the Jat struggles to contest and protest the rigorous land revenue policy of the Mughals. For example, in the year 1714, the Meo peasants who belonged to twenty villages of Pargana Khohri left their village because of the levying of heavy land revenue and took shelter in the Thun fort of Churaman Jat,69 which already had a strength of 12000 professional warriors. Churaman Jat even employed a number of Afghans from Bareilly and Sahajahanpur at a salary of ₹3 per day.70 There was a powerful section of the Gujjars of Helak and Sihi in the army of Jats. Harji Gujjar was the Commander in Chief who died while fighting in Delhi. Later on Raja Surajmal built Harji Kund as a memorial.71 It is evident that the Jats were not alone in their struggle, but were aided by other communities who lived close by. As a matter of fact, the local Jat zamindars strengthened the social base of the Jat movement during the Mughal period. Their army consisted of the farmers (irrespective of their caste) who were victims of heavy land revenue demands imposed on them by the Mughal State. For example, Amar Singh Jat of Tappa Khair in Kol (Aligarh) pargana, Nanda Jat and his son were very influential in the region of Khurja. Apart from these, Khemkaran Sogaria, Rati Ram Jat of Jargaon, Anceram, Roop Singh, Govind Ram, Daya Ram Jat of Medu, Bhure Singh and Chattar Singh Jat among others had a tremendous influence in their own region. They used to keep strong military contingents in their fortresses.72 They divided the booty amongst themselves.73 After the death of Churaman in 1721 AD, the Jat movement got divided into two segments and there was a power struggle between Badan Singh and Mohkam Singh (son of Churaman) which was resolved with the intervention of these local Jat Zamindars. The majority of these Zamindars were with Badan Singh as they were not happy with the quarrelsome and arrogant nature of Mohkam Singh.74 Moreover, even the Kachhwaha Raja Jai Singh of Amber had supported the cause of Badan Singh.75 In the year 1723, a Jat state was founded in Deeg which later on came to be known as the Bharatpur State.76 So we would again like to underline that during this long struggle of the Jats, Khap Panchayats had no role to play, that exists in any of the extensive set of records available to us.

sec.title: Khap Panchayat
sec.p: Given the spatial distribution of Jats it is not surprising that the major centre(s) of the activities of Khap Panchayat is comprised of the areas of Haryana, Western UP and the rural belt of the National Capital of Delhi. However, during the Mughal period these areas were in the jurisdiction of Delhi Suba from the administrative point of view.77 Some of the areas like Shahar, Narnaul and Koil (Aligarh) sarkars were located in the jurisdiction of Agra Suba.78 It is imperative to have a look at the spatial distribution and social status of the Jats in and around Delhi and Agra Suba at the end of the sixteenth century. The Delhi Suba comprised a total of 8 sarkars and 232 parganas. Of these 64 parganas had Jat Zamindaris and out of these 27 parganas were wholly under the control of the Jat zamindars and in 37 parganas the Jat had their shared Zamindari with other castes.79 The Agra Suba had a total of 13 sarkars comprising 203 parganas and Jats had their zamindaris in 22 parganas. Out of these, 5 parganas were under complete control of Jat zamindars (meaning only the Jat community) and in 17 parganas the Jats had shared zamindaris with other castes.80 Interestingly, these figures indicate that the Jats did not have much influence in the Delhi and the Agra Suba till the end of the sixteenth century. Most of the Parganas of Delhi Suba were placed in the category of Khalisa jagir (whose land revenue was directly deposited in the coffers of Mughal Emperor) and the rest of the Parganas were assigned in Tankhawah jagir to the Imperial mansabdars in lieu of their salaries. That is why in the Delhi Suba, the land revenue administrative officials of the Mughal period had considerable influence at the pargana as well as village level. So, to talk about the freedom and autonomy of the Khap Panchayats in this area would be misleading. The Ain-i-Akbari gives us the information that in many parganas of the Delhi Suba, along with the Jats, other caste zamindaris like Rajputs, Muslims and Brahmins existed, which implies that the village council consisted of mixed castes. For example, in 1665 AD, in pargana Chalkaliyana the Jats occupied 51.43 per cent zamindaris out of 100 villages, while 31.45 per cent and 17.14 per cent were controlled by the Rajputs and the Muslims respectively. Another important point is that the strengthening of the social position and identity of Jats took place only after the sixteenth century.81 It is further testified by the fact that later on during the period of Jat revolt (1668–1735 AD) in Agra Suba there was a considerable increase in Jat zamindaris.82

We would expect to find an institution like the Khap Panchayat to have grown in prominence over a long period of time. However the history of the Jats does not contain a single reference to the Khap Panchayat. Even settlement patterns do not furnish additional evidence. Nevertheless, for a better comprehension of the process of solidarity and to attempt to locate the role of Khap Panchayat, if any, it is important for us to analyze the social position of the Jats of Western UP right from the medieval period. The Ain-i-Akbari informs that out of a total of 22 parganas, only in 7 parganas, did the Jats have zamindaris. These 7 parganas were Kutana, Masudabad, Chaprauli, Tandah, Jhimjhimati, Jalabad and Jalalpur which are located in the modern Meerut district.83 The rest of the 15 parganas previously belonged to Tagas, Gurjars, Rajputs and Muslims, whereas gradually this area became dominated by the Jats.84 Similarly, in the area of modern Aligarh which was known as Koil Sarkar, according to Ain-i-Akbari, the majority of the parganas in this suba were dominated by the Rajputs and Muslim zamindaris. Thus it is apparent that there was no Jat zamindari in the Aligarh Sarkar till the end of the sixteenth century.85 Later on we find evidence in Rajasthani sources which suggest that by the end of the seventeenth century, the Jats had established their zamindari over many parganas in Koil (Aligarh) sarkar.86 During the eighteenth century, Jats had established big Talukdaris in the areas of Jawar, Murasan, Hathras and Iglas.87 These big Talukdaris played a major role in the establishment and later part of the military structure of the Bharatpur state. Two factors played an important role in the sudden rise of Jat zamindaris in the region of Western UP. The first one was that many new Jat settlers migrated to this region in search of land which was available in abundance. According to the Ain-i-Akbari, the major part of the area was heavily forested at the end of the sixteenth century and therefore offered possibilities for settlements. Second, during the period of the agrarian revolts, the Jats had successfully replaced the Gujjars and Tagas from their zamindaris and established their own zamindaris due to their superior military power and social position. The British land revenue officer of the time, Mr. Gillan noted,
The Jats are hard thrifty men, and it is hardly necessary to say, admirable cultivators. They are found all through the district (Meerut) and nearly everywhere in large numbers; but their chief possessions are in the north-west where they call their ‘Des’. It is said that they had invaded the district, driving out the Tagas.88

The Jats of Western UP are divided into 92 gotras most of which are similar to those of the Rajputs, for example, Tomar, Pawar, Rana, Chauhan, Gahlot and so on, from the ethnographic point of view. The Jats of these areas may be classified into two broad categories—Hales and Des—which are commonly known by the names of Pachhadas and Deswals.89 In common parlance, these are also known as Bagri and Deshwala. Earlier, dissimilarities prevented inter-caste marriages, although this is not the case today. The Deswals considered themselves to be the natives whereas the Pachchads were treated as ‘Baagris’ or outside settlers and as a result they were treated as inferiors. The Pachhads believe that their ancestors had settled here from the areas of Jaisalmer and Sindh around 1000 AD.90

Although the Khap Panchayats claim that they were the dominant community from the period of the Delhi Sultanate, the analysis in the foregoing sections demonstrates that the social position of the Jats remained weak till the end of the sixteenth century. In modern times, the most united form of panchayat has been found in Meham Chaubisi (Rohtak) (panchayat of 24 villages) and even this has representatives from different sections of society. Meham Chaubisi Sarvkhap Panchayat also claims to be an old institution but does not pretend to have any written farmans or documents issued by the Mughal authorities. Ch. Kabul Singh of Saurabh village (Mujaffarnagar district) has a number of farmans issued to the Jat Khap Panchayats by Emperor Akbar which are written in Hindi, although a number of Urdu words have also been incorporated. But when examined by a medieval historian, these documents from the Rajasthan state archives were not found to be genuine, as they are not written in Persian, which was the language of the State in the Mughal Empire. One can indentify Mughal farmans in two ways: first, ‘Allah-hu-Akbar’ meaning ‘God is Great’ is written at the top, and second, they always contain the seal of the Emperor. Along with the seal, we also find Tugra, the name of the Emperors and his ancestors inscribed on the farmans (the decorated signatures of the Emperor were termed as ‘Tugra’). The farmans in possession of the Khap Panchayats have neither the seals nor the Tugra of the Mughal Emperors.

In Western UP, there had been a good deal of ethnographical difference between the Pachhadas and the Deshwals, where the former were considered socially inferior to the latter. From the social and economic point of view however, the Pachhadas were far more advanced than the Deshwals. It seems probable that the Pachhadas claimed their own superiority by citing the Khap Panchayats. A similar history was also been written about the Marathas in the early twentieth century when their revolts against the Mughal state during the reign of Aurangzeb were projected as a ‘Hindu awakening’ or a kind of national movement. There seems to be no historical basis for concluding that such a history was written by the Jats highlighting the importance of Khap Panchayats.

The agrarian movements during the late seventeenth and early eighteenth centuries by the Jats against the Mughal Empire strengthened their social identity. During this period, the Jat zamindars were able to mobilize a large number of Jat peasants, in their fortress (grahis). The peasants of the surrounding villages used to assemble in the gharhis of the Jat zamindars hoping to get rid of their heavy land revenue burdens. This process not only strengthened the feeling of brotherhood among the Jat peasantry and Jat zamindars but it also provided a strong political and social identity to the Jat community. For example, the zamindars of Sinsini village (Raja Ram, Bhajja, Churaman and so on) were identified as Sinsinwal gotra Jats. Similarly the Sogaria and Sorot Jats made their gotra identity well recognized.91

The Jat Khap Panchayats have objected to marriages of boys and girls in same gotra, based on their social and cultural practices. The Khap Panchayats state that Jat society has found such practices unacceptable since ancient times and they claim to protect their cultural heritage by banning such intra-gotra marriages. Hence, it becomes necessary to discuss a few aspects of social and cultural elements in the history of the Jats. Historians have found that the origin of few Jat gotras in medieval times is linked to professions or locality, rather than a particular personality. Rajasthani documents and the reports from British ethnographers state that although Jat society did not follow any particular social customs and rituals for marriage in the pre-modern period, the Jats do not marry within their own gotra. Prabhu Dayal Mittal writes about the Braj Jats that they may marry the elder brother’s widow. This tradition separates them from other Hindus because in Hindu society, the elder brother’s wife has a social position, second only to the mother of the family. This is the reason that Jats are growing in a large number. Jat can keep any woman in their house after getting married with her. That is also why Jats had been considered as a lower or less Hindu caste.92

The Rajasthani documents bear out that Jats could and did marry women who belonged to other castes. To illustrate this fact, Giridhar Jat of pargana Jalalpur married the ex-wife of Murali Nai in 1739, and kept her with him without paying the Garecha tax (tax on re-marriage) to the state. When the matter was discovered, he was fined ₹20 by the Amil.93 Similarly, Prasa Jat of village Nainapur in pragana Harsana got married to an Ahir woman.94 In the same way, Nathu Jat of Jaisinghpura in pragana Maujpur got married to the ex-wife of Nanu Mali.95 In the Hashil Farohi column of Arsatta documents we find many examples in which the Jat community issued no restrictions to a person who wanted to get married to a woman from another caste. Jats therefore did not have restrictions or taboos about the customs and traditions regarding marriages. That is why a popular saying states that Jat ka kya Hindu aur Meo ka kya Musalman. This conveys that it is difficult to clearly equate the religion of Jats as Hindu, or the religion of the Meo as Muslim. Jats did not rigidly observe Hindu traditions, nor did Meos closely observe Muslim traditions. This saying thus captures the fluidity of these modern day categories like Jats being Hindus and Meos being Muslims. One can safely say that the Jat community stood apart from the rigid boundaries of Brahmanical Hindu order. Possibly this may be a reason why today the Jat gotras are more numerous than any other caste apart from the Brahmans. It also shows that from the Mughal period to the present, Jat communities have developed in strikingly different ways from other groups.

R.P. Rana has also shown in his study that the Jat community’s socio-cultural traditions and practices did not confirm with the rigid cultural religious of the Hindu caste system.96 Though most of the Haryana region remained untouched by the Bhakti movement in the medieval period, the influence of this monotheistic movement could be still seen in many places. The areas near to Rohtak are considered to be influenced by Nathpanthis. The Gaddi of Nathpanthis in Asthal Bohar village proves that nearby Jats may have been influenced by the ideology of Nathpanthis. The Nathpanthis by and large also rejected Brahamincal religious ideology.97 Since, the eighteenth century, Jats have been followers of the monotheistic ideology of Baba Haridas in rural areas of Delhi and Bahadurgarh (Haryana). Similarly Nischchal Das and Garibdas have been the religio-cultural preceptors of the Jats in the villages of Jhajjar district of Haryana.98 These saints were the followers and preceptors of Monotheistic ideology that challenged the Brahaminical ideology and dominance of the caste system. There has been much similarity between the Nathpanthis and the tenets of the Monotheistic religious ideology. Therefore, it will not be incorrect to state that the rural area of Rohtak, Jhajjar, Bahadurgarh and Delhi has never imitated rigid caste segregation, since the area was influenced by monotheistic ideology. Later on in the early twentieth century, these areas came under the influence of Arya Samaj, perhaps due to their already established inclinations towards monotheistic leanings. Subsequently, the Arya Samaj ideology led to the establishment of a large number of gurukuls in these areas.

sec.title: To Sum Up
sec.p: The discussion in the foregoing sections is a clear testimony that the claims of Khap Panchayat having long historical origins is difficult to sustain. Even a cursory look at the historical processes concerning the Jat community and the idea of the panchayat, is sufficient to challenge any such claim. We have tried to historically examine the nature of panchayats especially in Jat areas and argued that the nature of panchayats during the Mughal era was not fully explained by British officers and historians. The village panchayat was not an autonomous or independent organization in the Mughal period, and its area and reach of work were limited. Most of the quarrels and crimes that related to matters at the village level were sent to the office of the Amil and thus the panchayats had a very limited role, if any. When rural panchayats were neither autonomous nor independent then how is it possible to consider the autonomy and influence of Khap Panchayats?

It is important to take note of the followings factors. The Khap Panchayats are not common or popular throughout the greater Jat community. They are totally unknown in Bikaner, Churu, Sikkar, Jodhpur, Nagaur, Merta, Ganganagar and Hanumangarh districts of Rajasthan, where a large number of Jat peasants have been residing since medieval times. In Haryana also the Jat peasants of Sirsa district are not familiar with the Khap panchayat. Similarly, there was no organization like the Khap Panchayat in the medieval period which was independent and autonomous in character. Such a claim is not supported by any contemporary historical document. An important document relied on by the Jats is a handwritten booklet by Pandit KanhaRam which mentions dates and meetings of the events related to Sarvakhap Panchayats since medieval times. Very few of the dates from this booklet actually match with the dates of historical events. Moreover, it is necessary to verify the historicity of the booklet of Pandit KanhaRam itself. First, the booklet claims that the Sarvakhap Panchayats were independent and autonomous in their decision making. Second, they are supposed to have opposed the anti-Hindu policies of the Mughal emperors and the Sultans of Delhi. Third, they were supposedly motivated by national consciousness and hence fought against the Muslim invaders, for instance, Mohammad Ghauri in the the twelfth century, Tamurlane in the late fourteenth century, Babur in the early fifteenth century and Ahmad Shah Abdali99 in the third battle of Panipat in 1761 AD. This contention appears quite untenable in the absence of corroborative information. Babur in his Baburnama has given a very good description of the battle of Khanwah and has described all the names of petty Rais and rulers who came in support of Rana Sanga to fight against Babur. But the Baburnama never once mentions anything about the role of the Jats or their panchayats. In the same way, it is not supported by any historical source that Jats fought in favour of Maratha Sardar Bhave in the third battle of Panipat.

It is important to realize that it was only after the year 1960, with the politics of Chaudhry Charan Singh, that a well defined identity of the Jats of Western UP took concrete shape. During this phase, based upon their own gotras, numerous Khaps also came into existence which, were earlier in an embryonic stage, if present at all. These Khaps produced a number of local political leaders. In the politics of Haryana also, these Khaps came to hold sway only after the period of the Emergency. Even in Haryana the rise of Khap Panchayats can be attributed, on the lines of Western UP, to the politics of Chaudhry Devilal.
Recently, Khap Panchayats have started issuing new orders for its members and are attempting to even amend the Hindu Marriage Act of 1955.

It is no surprise to note that as a matter of fact Khap Panchayats are patriarchal in nature. Regrettably, one of the decisions of Khap Panchayats is as follows: a meeting of the Khap Panchayat was held in the Sisana village on 23 March, 1993 (Sunday) hosted by the Dahiya Khap of the Jats, in which more than one lakh people (the sarpanches) from Haryana, Delhi, UP, Punjab and Rajasthan participated.100 The Sarvkhap was headed by Chaudhry Ramphal Dahiya, the head of Dahiya Khap. The decisions taken in the panchayat concerning women are as follows: Sarvkhap unanimously decided that rights of a girl should be decided following from the property of the husband rather than on the property of the father. Only in the absence of a brother should the inheritance rights be passed on to the daughter(s). The Sarvkhap believes in equality of education and girls should be educated like boys but instead of co-educational schools and colleges, we should have separate schools and colleges for girls. The girls or the women of the family should not be taken for Barat (marriage party). The Sarvkhap also opposed the 33 per cent women reservation given to them by the Panchayati Raj. These bodies have always opposed the right of inheritance for women. Under the pressure of these Khap Panchayats, the government of Haryana made an amendment in the right to inheritance, and sent it to the President for approval. However, this was dismissed by the Hon’ble President. Thus Khap Panchayats in their approach appear to be not only resisting democratic institutions but are even anti-women.

It will not be incorrect to suggest that the changed social composition of these panchayats tells us a lot about their growing conservatism. As mentioned earlier, in a few districts of Haryana and Western UP, Jats enjoy considerable influence on the basis of their population. They are the owners of extensive farming lands and also enjoy a dominant place in local administration and politics. However, in the recent past it has been observed that the Khap Panchayats are being actively dominated by retired army officers or civil officers, who use it as platform to project their own political image. These people do not hesitate to raise sensitive issues like gotra and matrimonial disputes. On the pretext of safeguarding culture and tradition the Khap Panchayats are being harnessed to gain political mileage and to exploit the ignorance of the local populace by creating mass hysteria.

In the Jat community if a boy and a girl marry in the same gotra, the Khap Panchayats declare them to be criminals and violators of their social code of conduct. Khap Panchayats put forth the argument that people of the same gotras have a common ancestor referred to as Dada. The couple belonging to the same gotra are like siblings and thus, they cannot marry each other. The basic character of most of the Khap Panchayats is patriarchal and most of its policies are anti-women. Even a glimpse of the system of justice meted out by these Panchayats is a clear testimony of its true character. I would like to conclude that Khap Panchayats do not have any legitimacy or historical basis. They do not have any basis in ancient social institutions, but are of recent origin and have come into existence in the context of modern social, political and economic conditions.

Kanha Ram, Untitled Pothi (In possession of Chaudhary Qabul Singh village Shoram, Dist. Muzaffarnagar) containing 16 wrongly bound leaves written on both sides. The first leaf, though mutilated, mentions Samvat 1840. The visible difference in ink and size of letters suggests its gradual compilation. Even if began in Samrat 1840, it was completed at a later date. Its author, Pandit Kanharam is said to have been a person of local repute and was a resident of village Shoram, Dist. Muzaffarnagar. This manuscript written in bad Hindi, is an unconnected compilation mostly from earlier but now untraceable pothis and partly from the author’s own observation, showing the activities of the Jats and other local people, especially of the Doah and Haryana region during the Medieval times. Its earlier portion (leaves 3a–11a) refers to the meetings of the Sarvakhap Panchayat held in Samat 1252, 1254 (in a Jungle near Baraut), 1256, 1305, 1352 (Bhokharhedi) 1317 (Libberhedi), 1344 (Shikarpur), 1383 (Sisauli), 1408 (in a Jungle near Sishauli), 1455 (in a Jungle of Chaugama), 1460 (Sikarpur), 1547 (in a jungle near Baraut), 1560 (Bavali), 1584, 1597 (Kairana), 1613 (Nisarh), 1621 (Shoram), 1665 (Khekaram), 1686 (Nisarh), 1718 (Chhaprauli), 1727, 1764 (Bhaisewal), 1766 (Karnal) and 1817 (Sisauli). The latter part of the Pothi (leaves 11a–16b) bound reversely, enumerate the social customs of the Jats and other people and the nature, scope, formation and functioning of the Sarvakhap Panchayat. The dates in some cases are incorrect and the numbers of participants in the Sarvakhap Panchayat meetings and of local militia raised for any battle seems to be highly inflated. See G.C.
